the more interactive the case will feel, even though there
will be roughly 15-20 endings.

Added Death Codes functionality

In my management system, I've added the idea of death codes. In
this case, you can specify precisely the kind of "death" that occurs
because in RPG's "death" can be somewhat ambiguous. A death code
thus refers to whether you've died a biological death, been turned
into various forms of undead, be turned to stone, etc.

The death codes are as follows: Death code starts at 0 (you no longer
exist), Add 1 if the body is still present (death). Add 2 if you
can move. Add 4 if your normal biology is the same. Add 8 if
free will remains. Add 16 if the character still retains memory of
previous existence. Add 32 if the condition can be reversed
by the same means the "death" was caused, such as a spell that
can be dissipated.

Scores have been calculated for common RPG deaths: annihilation,
death, petrification, zombification, etc. They are in a death_codes
SQL Table. Plans are also to add 64 (or more) to create
a custom code. This would be if multiple types of death events
that need to be distinguished for "death types" should they
end up with the same score (i.e. the six questions distinguishing
death events fail to make a necessary distinction. A test case
might be zombies. Zombies from viruses, zombies from parasites,
and supernatural zombies all mindless crave the flesh and brains
of humans, but an RPG based on Resident Evil (where multiple
zombie types coexist). Might need to track those differences.

Removed_from_play field added to deaths table

The possibility arose that in an rpg setting. You might want to
record a character death without the character being considered
removed from play. Character might get resurrected, be undead,
survive as a ghost, etc. and thus be playable after having died.

The code doesn't support this feature, and table constraints (primary
keys) need to be dropped as well for the computer to not encounter an
error.

It's also worth mentioning that a transaction, once started, needs to
be committed. Otherwise it will never record. I've added the pdo::commit
method here.

Added PDO an transaction support for deaths.php

I added the more OO based PDO class instead of using a mysqli
connection object. This should do a better job at telling me
when / why a mysql query didn't work, along with making my code

Also added transaction support. When my sql queries are sent, one
depends on the other. One of my statements has been failing due to
a key restraint, so here I catch the failing sql statement and don't
add info to either one.

commit_list.message:
Sketch MVC Approach from scratch

Previous Coding Efforts left me with one big, unmanageable array.
Something particularly irksome is that I didn't a way to handle
small json files with one or two pieces of information so that they
would load the same way big json files would. I was left with an too
weakly typed giant array that would have been a mess to maintain.

This approach has two major differences. It starts writing tests before
code is written and involves an MVC approach, with a base controller
class that should have most of the game's required methods and child
classes that have more specific ones.

The following code tests one method of the Base Controller Class.

scene shouldn't be filled with too much philosophy, even in a tale like

Added License: CC-Attribution-ShareAlike

After research I've decided to put this under a Creative Commons
license, with attribution / sharealike, with the aim the people
can adapt the work at their leisure, without taking credit for
the original work.

New Chapter: Dr. Creed and Electra's sex scene

This is where the male lead and female lead finally pair off. A few
things to note. Creed should have utterly botched things with Margot.
He should have an established habit of failing to get the girl, so
that the reader may not actually be sure about their pairing.

Admittedly, I have not taken the time to make Creed different from
myself, and despite the reader's likely skepticism of the event,
the scene is actually based on a real event. Make sure that doesn't
keep you from writing it in a way that's best for the story

New Chapter: The middleocean

In this scene, Creed comes to a realization about his former life.
The story begins with Creed a frustrated academic, where he can feel
as though he's become a caricature of himself. He's been struggling
to get a serious history paper published, whilst, humiliatingly,
he is making quite a bit of money by being a scholar on an unscholarly
topic: Atlantis.

This is where he comes to the realization that he's failed to get a
grasp on what history really is. History is about consensus. It's
about gathering documents that can be considered independent of each
other but which corroborate.

Biblical history, for instance, is constrained by how little surviving
non-biblical sources exist that could verify its accounts. Creed has
focused his efforts on a topic where consensus can't be reached (not
enough documents) and thus hasn't been doing history, but something
else, something more suited to myth and legend.

That he is being well paid for an audience that wants myth and legend
and disregarded by those that don't. A novel historical source is
very much like a hade, a glimpse into a reality that could so very
different but its elusive and hard to quantify.

This moment is supposed to be the point of no return, Joseph Campbell's
crossing the threshold, where Creed has to start acting on the vision
that he's receiving. But what should he do? That's still a huge
sticking point.

I've included some sketches on the overarching story from the

stick) black goop. The new story features dangerous experiments
done on said goop by the military, and an after to stop it.

Wrote Notes for The Culinary Black Arts

After working on some drafts and doing some thinking, I have an idea
on the story. Involving, surprise, three characters you wouldn't
suspect of working together, working together, despite their
differences. There's a military plot they have to uncover and foil.

Started the chapter with Margot

In this chapter, the character Margot is introduced. Storywise she's
on the run after killing a high level military official. After landing
an initial blow in self defense, she finished the job when the victim
was prone. She's still in shock from the affair and acting quite
suspicious.

My plans for this chapter is for Margot to get drunk, make a pass at
Dr. Creed (which he refuses), and then feel embarrassed about it
afterward. Her basic thrust as a character is to put as much
psychological distance between herself and the murder.

She's happy with Creed for not taking advantage of her, and uses some
of the confusion to ask him hypothetical questions regarding the murder.
Which makes him a tad sexually uncomfortable. When Dr. Creed meets his
lady later on in the novel, I'd like for it to be a tad difficult and
uncomfortable. For a surprise sexual union to just as much as a "Hade"
than inexplicable red ooze or incorpeal killer bees.

New Scene Draft: "The Garden..."

Scene Status: Complete::Staging

Synopsis: The scene introducing the motives
of military involvement in the Theatre of
HADES main plot.

The story revolves around the image of
metal consuming plants that defy the rules
of biology and remove toxic heavy metals
from the soil.

The dual potential for this is noted by
the military figure Dobson. All involved
see the plants as a way of removing the
traces of the horrors of war. However,
it is really only the memory of those
horrors that can stop new wars, which
Dobson realizes.

The story offers three choices: Mark's decision
to leave on ethical grounds, Margot's decision
to "pay to play", or Margot's ultimate decision
to use deadly force.

New Scene: "Bank of Secrets"

Scene Status: Bank of Secrets => Complete::Staging

Scene Synopsis: My third draft of the Bank of Secrets,
revolves around the setting of the Bank of Secrets and
the fatal affair between Jonas and Rachel.

Previous versions of the story revolved around complex
secret keeping mechanisms. This story introduces the
idea of a "secrets loan", and a "secrets pool". The first
is an agreement by the user to tell little secrets over
time to the bank, in exchange for keeping a big secret
quickly. The second is the concept that a large pool
of small secrets would be worth more than a few big
secrets.

The character arc of the story revolves around Jonas'
new position, a promotion from the loaning and pool
management system to a department responsible for
timing human deaths. Jonas tries to cheat this system
to save a former high school crush. Jonas does have
a sort of incubus nature, women aren't better off
for engaging in a relationship.

Culinary Black Arts, simplified

This new version of the Culinary Black Arts
seeks to simplify what is otherwise a long
and potentially rather distracting tale.

The insatiety and appetite as conveyed in a
town's social degeneration is now conveyed
in the degeneration of specific individuals.
The story also offers a critique of Christianity
inside a film of the Theatre of HADES. No other
film does this.

The Explanation, At Last

These final two chapters resolve Creed's personal
challenges. In short, Creed was focused on an
intellectual dead end that nearly no one cared about
but himself.

Understanding the nature of this dead end he faces
the reality that he was unable to imagine. That he
would reenter a community he viewed to be based on
imprisoning dogma as a challenger and disruptor:
One that can add academic skepticism to the Christian
narrative, taught in the original Greek. His desire
to speculate and imagine now articulated in a manner
religious students would find relevant in their own
lives.

The Squid Introduces the Minister

A grotesque humanoid with squid like characteristics
is now seeking to interrogate Creed. This creature
confronts Creed with his great unexpressed fear--
that the action in the story is a daydream of
his high school years. Creed lives the experience
of "waking up" and confronting everything he has
been trying to avoid in his life.

This particular chapter has a sticky problem that
can only be tackled with effective writing. Creed
is meant to actually believe it was all "just a
dream". He confronts his past whilst experiencing
it as his present.

There is nothing in the narrative previously that
would contradict the idea that everything that's
happened is a phantasm and thus unimportant. This
chapter needs to be a solid rejection of that
interpretation and then bring the reader back to
the main narrative.

Raven's Flight from the Wind Chimes

This features a chapter in which Creed and
company escape their prison. It currently
feels the escape requires too many long odds.
Of course action sequences always require
long odds. The current version really puts
an age restraint on Cora (her bathroom
solution would only occur to a child at
a certain developmental process.

New Chapter: "The Collapse..."

Status: Annotated::Staging

Synopsis: (Author's Note, this commit includes three
chapters because two were altered in response to the
writing of The Collapse of the Tower of Words).

After the manowar incident, Creed, Electra, and Cora
are apprehended by a Russian military squad and taken
to a base somewhere about a ten hour drive for Greece,
outside the border. Creed is stuck with merely
waiting, and we don't see the other two characters.
The Russian interrogator Anna seems to know Creed has
been coming into contact with manifestations of HADES
and the earthly branch of its Theatre, but wishes the
full summary. She is gathering information as to
whether Creed has seen to much and should be shot.

However, someone behind the Theatre of HADES, someone
who sames to have an active and more knowledgable role
in Creed's adventure, relieves Anna of her duty before
Creed dies of poisoning. He offers Creed a substance
known as the Blood of Apollo, which will give him a
vision offering a choice. He is offered the chance
to martyr himself for an important lost scroll or
to let historical distortion remain. He chooses
the later. The man leaves, but his departure does
not seem to indicate an end to his quest.

Tags: [Military][Ambiguity][Culture][Falling Monolith]
Characters: {Dr. Creed}{Anna the Interrogator}{Unknown HADES
agent}{Lydia}

New Chapter: "He Who..."

Status: Annotated::Staging

Synoposis: Dr. Creed wavers on his decision to
take a series of flights to Greece, only to
find a poem, stuffed in his passenger's
seat titled He Who The Angels Fear to Change.
This poem revolves around an angelic chorus, and
Satan's insistence not to stay bound to it.
The poem itself deals with a topic: how does
one love things that can change? In the case
of the Angels   it is Fear.

Reflecting on this topic indirectly leads to
Creed gathering his courage to meet a hacker
named Electra in the obscure Greek town of
Kavala. They talk, and Electra tells a
newspaper story of a cave discovery not
subsequently printed anywhere else. They
follow this lead and find a Theatre of Hades,
leading them to the film, the Garden of Treason.

Tags: [Love][Change][The Threshold][Satanic Independence]
Characters: {Dr. Creed}{Electra Samaras}
